parts: This method is commonly carried out in low-pressure argon or oxygen; organic residue may be broken down by reactive oxygen species and short-wave UV radiation emitted in this technique.
Sterilizing growth media, surgical equipment or some biohazardous waste often requires use of this high-pressure device. Another version of this device may be used to convert gels to aerogels.
This chemical is often used in the lab for easy cleaning and fast drying of glassware, although this simplest ketone is also the basis for many nail polish removers.
Name this process, which may be initiated by a landlord, in which families are expelled from their rented homes. So-called "informal" types of this process may include paying off tenants to move.
This Princeton sociologist's book Evicted won the 2017 Pulitzer Prize for his study of eight families in Milwaukee trying to find housing.

Desmond’s Evicted is an example of this type of method, in which the researcher is immersed in the daily lives of the target population in an attempt to document them. It involves documenting the results of participant observation and fieldwork.
Name this novel, in which Briony Tallis misconstrues the relationship between her sister Cecilia and Robbie Turner and later gets Robbie sent to prison by accusing him of raping her cousin Lola.
This British author of Amsterdam and Saturday is better known for creating Briony and Cecilia Tallis in Atonement.
In Atonement, after Robbie accidentally sends Cecilia a private draft of an explicit love letter, the two of them notably have sex in one of these places.

answers: MacArthur [or Arthur MacArthur; or Douglas Macarthur]
parts: Name this Tennessee battle where Union troops under Virginian George Henry Thomas stormed the rifle pits up the namesake geographical feature. This battle resulted in the lifting of the Confederate siege of Chattanooga.

One man with this surname won the Medal of Honor for planting his regimental colors on Missionary Ridge with the cry “On Wisconsin!” George Marshall gave his son of this surname the same award after he and his staff evacuated from Corregidor Island on four PT boats.

After Missionary Ridge, Abraham Lincoln promoted this commanding officer at the battle to Lieutenant General, a rank previously reserved for George Washington. This general succeeded Andrew Johnson as President.
Name this stringed instrument of the lute family native to the Indian subcontinent. It was played by Ravi Shankar.

The sympathetic strings of the sitar are tuned to these melodic patterns which form the basis of improvisation in Hindustani music. They are analogous to scales and modes, and the behavior of their notes is called chalan.

While Hindustani music featuring the sitar was heavily influenced by contact with Persia, this style of southern Indian music remained more voice-oriented. Kriti form the core repertoire of this tradition, which is characterized by complex rhythms or tala.

answers: married priests [accept reasonable descriptions; accept clergy in place of priests]
parts: Identify this distinction commonly given in Latin as “viri probati.” The synod in the Amazon will be held in October 2019 to discuss this distinction.
This Protestant reformed set a precedent for clerical marriage by marrying Katharina von Bora. He is better known for nailing his 95 theses to the door of the All Saints’ Church in Wittenburg.
The aforementioned Wissam Akiki is a member of the clergy of this oldest Eastern Catholic church, based in Bkerke (“ib-KER-key”), Lebanon.

answers: conic sections [or conics, prompt on answers mentioning cones]
parts: Name this category of curves, including ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas, that can be obtained from the intersection of a plane with a certain three-dimensional shape.

Conic sections were studied by this Greek mathematician, who also names a theorem stating that the sum of the square of two sides of a triangle equals the square of the length of the median dividing the third side plus the square of half the length of the third side.
For any point on a conic section, the conic’s eccentricity is equal to the ratio of the point’s distance to a focus and its distance to this line.
Name this merchant republic centered at the port of Dubrovnik in modern-day Croatia.

Ragusa fell under the domination of this other Adriatic merchant republic during the Fourth Crusade. Besides invading Ragusa, this republic’s doge Enrico Dandolo used the crusaders to sack the Byzantine capital.
After a Russo-Ottoman fleet captured this formerly-Venetian island group from France in 1799, they established oligarchic Septinsular Republic based on the model of Ragusa.
Name these objects, which have a dialogue asking "did the hand then of [their maker] shake?" before "one of the loquacious Lot" asks who they are and who is their maker.
Name this poem which features the metaphor of the pots. It also claims that "The Bird of Time...is on the wing" and describes an object which "having writ, moves on."
This polymath poet asked for only "a jug of wine, a loaf of bread, and thou" in the Rubaiyat.

answers: National Rally [or Rassemblement national; accept NR or RN]
parts: Name this British politician, one of the major supporters of the 'Leave' campaign. A founding member of UKIP, he now leads the Brexit Party.
Farage and UKIP have been identified as part of a growing right-wing populist trend in Europe, along with this French party once called the National Front. This party is led by Marine Le Pen.

The popularity of European populist parties may correlate with this attitude, whose adherents include Henri Joyeux and Andrew Wakefield. In August 2019, the UK government announced plans to convene a summit of social media companies to address this attitude.

Name this action, which is undertaken by an unnamed narrator of a Denis Johnson short story in the collection Jesus’ Son. He consumes drugs and alcohol given to him by strangers he meets while performing this action.
In this novel, Kilgore Trout hitchhikes to Midland City, where he meets Dwayne Hoover, who, after reading Trout’s writing, believes that he is the only person in the universe with free will.
Jack Kerouac included his experiences with hitchhiking in this novel, in which Sal Paradise and Dean Moriarty travel across America and meet other fictionalized figures from the Beat movement.
Name this sun deity who only emerged from her cave after Ame-no-Uzume performed a lewd dance for her. That dance inspired the kagura often performed in Japanese theater.

These people performed the sanghyang dance to depict the struggle between Barong and the demon Rangda, who was conflated with Durga. These people believe that the world serpent Antaboga created the world turtle Bedwang.
The aforementioned sanghyang dance somewhat resembles the Chinese lion dance, inspired by the monster Nian, who was chased away by objects with this color.
Atomic spectral lines can be split by an electric field in this effect. This effect is the electrical counterpart of the Zeeman effect.
Howard Moseley developed an expression for the spectral emission lines of atoms in this part of the spectrum. That expression only depends on quantity atomic number minus one squared.

In general, calculating the spectra of multi-electron atoms is challenging because this quantum mechanical equation becomes impossible to solve exactly. Its time-independent form is written “H-psi equals E-psi.”
Name this Canadian province, whose premier Jacques Parizeau blamed the ‘No’ vote of a 1995 sovereignty referendum on “money and the ethnic vote.”
Charles de Gaulle appeared in Montreal at this mid-century event and declared “Vive le Québec libre!”
Expo 67 occurred in the midst of this socializing, secularizing revolution, which followed the “The Great Darkness” of Maurice Duplessis’ (“DOO-pless-ee’s”) time as premier of Quebec.

answers: basset-horn [do not accept or prompt on “horn” alone]
Prague [or Praha] (That composer is Bedřich Smetana.)
parts: Name this composer, whose other serenades include Eine kleine Nachtmusik for string ensemble.

Mozart called for three of these obscure woodwinds in his Masonic Funeral Music and two in his Serenade in B-flat, K. 361. Despite its name, this instrument is a member of the clarinet family, with a range that extends about a fifth lower than a standard clarinet.

Mozart’s clarinet concerto, originally planned for basset-horn, was premiered in this city. Mozart's Symphony No. 38 is nicknamed for this city, and a later composer depicted a castle here in the tone poem Vyšehrad (“vi-SHE-he-rad”).
Name this father of population genetics. This biologist’s namesake “dilemma” claims that selection cost for positive traits is insufficient in explaining high mutation rates observed in species.
Haldane’s dilemma was resolved by Motoo Kimura, who hypothesized that most mutations generated by genetic drift are functionally in this state where they are neither beneficial nor detrimental.

The neutral theory predicts that the diversity within a species is directly proportional to this quantity. For humans, this value is currently just above seven billion, and the carrying capacity is the maximum of this value.
Name this thinker who co-authored Hegemony and Socialist Strategy with Ernesto Laclau. She criticized “third way” liberal politics in The Democratic Paradox.
Mouffe draws strongly from this Italian Marxist, who first theorized the concept of hegemony in his Prison Notebooks.
The third part of the Prison Notebooks is dedicated to the philosophy of this concept. Gramsci loosely defined this concept as a conscious activity that aims at a political goal.

answers: Spanish Golden Age [or Siglo de Oro]
parts: Name this rival of the poet Francisco de Quevedo whose culteranismo style opposed Quevedo’s conceptismo.
Góngora and Quevedo were both members of this period of flourishing of Spanish arts and literature.

This author was a member of the “Generation of ‘27,” formed to commemorate the 300th anniversary of Gongora’s death. He wrote poems like “Death of a Bullfighter” before being executed in the Spanish Civil War.

answers: Barmakids [or Barmecides; or Barmakīyān; or al-Barāmikah]
parts: Name this Abbasid caliph whose personal library became Baghdad’s House of Wisdom under the patronage of his successors. This caliph famously gifted an elephant and a water clock to Charlemagne.
Harun Al-Rashid appears frequently in One Thousand and One Nights with his vizier Ja’far, who hailed from this influential Persian family.

The Barmakids traced back to the hereditary pramukh administrators of Nava Vihara, a monastery of this religion in Balkh. Xuanzang, a Chinese monk of this religion, described Nava Vihara in his account of his travels.

answers: self-portraits of Gustave Courbet [prompt on partial answers]
A Burial At Ornans [or Un enterrement à Ornans; or A Funeral At Ornans]
parts: Name both the genre of paintings and their artist. One of these works by this artist prominently features a cello, while another shows the wide eyed central figure pulling his hair back in anxiety and is titled The Desperate Man.
For the 1850 Salon, Gustave Courbet used the gigantic scale of history painting for this painting that depicts a funeral for his great-uncle in his hometown.

While not posing for his friend Courbet’s The Artist’s Studio, this poet and art critic savaged the mechanical nature of photography and defined the modern artist as a spectator in The Painter of Modern Life.
